datafield.subfield: Lecture recorded at Bailey Hall, September 30, 1974.
Sponsored by the Cornell Chapter of the National Association for Justice.
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Sponsored by: Society for the Humanities.
Speaker(s): Class of 1916 Professor of English and professor of comparative literature at Cornell University.

Culler discusses the interpretation of the Romantic poets set forth in The Mirror & the Lamp,' a work of literary criticism by M. H. Abrams, and suggests that modern interpretations of the works of the Romantic poets have developed within the context of the metaphor set forth within this book.
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Sponsored by: Kappa Alpha Theta,Biological Sciences, Division of.

Goodall discusses the world of the chimpanzee, focusing in particular on the Gombe chimp. She uses a film and a slide presentation as visual aids in her description of the individual behavior of the animals, their social structure, mating practices, and ability to learn and understand language and sign language.
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Speaker(s): Author; professor at Howard University; Cornell alumnus.

Toni Morrison gives a talk entitled, "A Matter of Fiction," which discusses why people write and read fiction, specifically relating her own motivations. Morrison focuses on the preservation of the oral tradition as her primary motivation.
A study of modern and postmodern architecture through architectural details
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Koolhas discusses modernist and post-modernist ideas in architecture through study of a number of architectural details.
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Sponsored by: Society for the Humanities,Latin American Studies Program,Romance Studies, Department of.
Discusses the unequaled importance of language in the perception of history.
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Sponsored by: Society for the Humanities,Western Societies Program,History, Department of.

After explaining that a feeling of crises within the field of intellectual history has motivated introspection into the nature and objectives of the field, LaCapra discusses existing approaches and outlines alternative methods of addressing issues in intellectual history.
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
This recording includes approximately 30 min. of a press conference given in conjunction with the lecture. Abbie Hoffman discusses the media, the government and his protest activites.
Horns, beans and insteps: guessing from Aristotle to Sherlock Holmes
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
A comparative discussion about semiotics and logic in Sherlock Holmes, Aristotle, and other analytical philosophers.
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.

Sponsored by: Student Finance Commission,Friends of Israel,Jewish Studies Program,Council on the Creative and Performing Arts,Temple Beth-El,Sigma Phi Fraternity,University Unions Programming Board,Near Eastern Studies, Department of,Young Israel House,Young Judea.
Singer discusses the significance of cabala--the Jewish theology based on a cipher method of interpreting the scripture--to the sceptical, scientific modern man.
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.

Sponsored by: University Unions Program Board,Interfraternity Council,Sigma Chi,Alpha Delta Phi,Panhellenic Council,Women's Studies Program,Women's resource Center,Alpha Phi Omega,Mortar Board Honor Society,ILR Student Government,Unions and Activities, Department of.
Steinem criticizes the Reagan administration for its stance on issues concerning women, abortion, and minorities. She discusses the need for the more unified organization of women in politics.
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Speaker(s): Painter; Director, Haffburger Graduate School of Painting, Merrill Institute.
Hartigan discusses her background as an artist and gives a slide show of her works, discussing the history of each painting.
Adrienne Rich reads her own poetry
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Speaker(s): Andrew D. White Professor-at-Large; poet and leading feminist thinker.
Rich reads a collections of her poems which illustrate her feminist views on issues such as the Holocaust, racism and sexuality.
Theory of architecture: conflicting roles of myth
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Choay outlines the concepts of myth, history, and remembrance and their relationship to the built environment.
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Bishop discusses contemporary literature from Fitzgerald to Diddeon as a frame for absolution.
The role of the writer in Cuba
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Sponsored by: Cuban Student Society,Latin American Studies Program,Student Finance Commission.
Padella discusses the role of the writer in communist Cuba where he is seen not as a hero, but as an unglorified contributor to social justice.
Restlessness and stability in present day painting
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Sponsored by: Council on the Creative and Performing Arts.
Kahn discusses current, important issues in art and relates them to contemporary examples in painting.
Alice R. Friman reads her own poetry
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Friman reads three poems which deal with different aspects of the life of King Midas, the man who was given the "golden touch".
Thoughts on the future of music
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Lutoslawski discusses the construction of music in the past and explains how the past affects the future of music.
La cultura caribena en la Cuba actual: continuidad versus reptura
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Benitez-Rojo describes the Caribbean influence on Cuban culture.
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Sponsored by: Society for the Humanities.
Woodring defines the age of romanticism.
All the world's a stage: an insider's perspective on "Hill Street Blues"
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Sponsored by: Interfraternity Council,Dean of Students Office,Graduate School,Council on the Creative and Performing Arts,The Theatre of Ideas.
Speaker(s): Former actor on "Hill Street Blues"; alumnus of Cornell.
Marinaro talks of his career as a pro football player and as an actor, explaining the adjustment from athlete to actor.
Kurt Vonnegut, Jr. lectures about his work
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Sponsored by: Sigma Phi Fraternity,Cornell Daily Sun,University Unions Programming Board.
Vonnegut describes life as a Cornell undergraduate and the way to become a "successful" writer.
The principle of reason and the idea of the university
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Sponsored by: Andrew D. White Professors-At-Large Program.
Derrida discusses a university's "reason to be", its meaning and distinction.
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Speaker(s): Cook is professor emerita in the New York State School of Industrial and Labor Relations.
Cook explores the dimensions of women's increased labor force participation in the United States.
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Baranczak discusses the effect of martial law on poetry in Poland.
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
McGovern describes his plans if elected in 1984 and discusses some of the problems facing the Reagan administration.
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Robeson introduces two films of his father's which present views of the black actor.
Katerina Anghelaki-Hook reads her own poetry
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Sponsored by: Hellenic Student Association,Ithaca Community Poets.
Anghelaki-Rooke's poems recall her Greek ancestry.
A gathering of spirit: a reading of North American Indian womens' writing
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Brant reads and discusses a selection of poetry written by Native American women.
Gay people and civil rights: how far, how fast
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Stoddard describes gay rights at both the federal and state levels, as well as at Cornell University.
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Women and the West German peace movement
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Sponsored by: Peace Studies Program,Women's Studies Program.
Wettig-Danielmeier dicusses the role of women in West German politics and the peace movement.
Alternative choices: solutions to modern man's problems
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Ba-Yunus presents a personal assessment of the current state of Islam in the Middle East.
The seizure of Willard Straight Hall and its meaning for today: a fifteen year retrospective
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Sponsored by: Interfraternity Council,Ujamaa Residential College,Willard Straight Hall Programming Board.
Panel looks back on the Willard Straight Hall takeover from various perspectives.
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.

Kennedy describes the "place" of women in the legal profession.
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Lowi and Ginsberg discuss the possibility and probability of Reagan being defeated in the upcoming election.
The United States and the Wider World
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Howard examines the weaknesses of the United States' foreign policy.
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Sponsored by: Sigma Phi Fraternity,Ithaca Filmmakers at Cornell (IFMAC),Willard Straight Hall Programming Board.
Dubelman gives a professional's perspective on writing, producing, and directing for the motion picture and television industry.
USA, developing nations and world community
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Sponsored by: Interreligious International Ministries Committee (IRIM),Center for World Community.
USA, developing nations and world community, part 2
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Sponsored by: Interreligious International Ministries Committee (IRIM),Center for World Community.
Mbata presents his view of a future "global village".
The political iconography of the new world: the foundation myth in Catholic, Protestant and Native icons
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Sponsored by: Romance Studies, Department of,Society for the Humanities,American Studies Program,Women's Studies Program,Arts and Sciences, College of.
Lopez-Baralt traces the history and development of European iconography and emblems in the New World.
Political iconography of the New World.
Ways toward peace in the world community
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Sponsored by: Center for World Community,Interreligious International Ministries Committee (IRIM).
Cotton discusses the need for global understanding between nations.
Lecture on current Latin American politics
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Bras discusses the United States' dominance of Puerto Rico and its resistance to granting independence to the island.
The problem of believing preliminaries to an historical anthropology of believability
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
deCerteau discusses the role of belief in primitive cultures.
The nuclear arms race: why it is so hard to deal with
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
York describes the nuclear arms race and the problems inherent in dealing with it.
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Sponsored by: Andrew D. White Professors-At-Large Program,Romance Studies, Department of.
Derrida discusses different ideas of, feelings about, and cultural groupings of inventions and invention methods.
The nuclear arms race: what might be done
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
York explores the history of, and politics behind, the nuclear arms race. He suggests steps which the United States government and universities can take in order to halt the cold war.
Invention in the nuclear age--no apocalypse, not now
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Sponsored by: Peace Studies Program,University Lectures Committee,Western Societies Program,Arts and Sciences, College of,Women's Studies Program,Romance Studies, Department of.
Derrida distinguishes between the fiction and reality of nuclear war, places the nuclear age within the context of history, and clarifies the role of the critic in nuclear discourse.
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Speaker(s): Professor of sociology at the Frankfurt School, West Germany.
Habermas analyzes the philosophical discourse surrounding modernity and postmodernity.
The Philosophical discourse on modernity and postmodernity.
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Speaker(s): Professor of sociology at the Frankfurt School, West Germany.
Habermas examines Nietzsche's interpretations of the modernity and postmodernity debate.
The philosophical discourse on modernity and postmodernity.
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Speaker(s): Professor of sociology at the Frankfurt School, West Germany.
Habermas discusses the theories of Heidegger and their relation to modernity, postmodernity and rationalism.
The philosophical discourse on modernity and postmodernity.
Bataille: between eroticism and economy of nature
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Speaker(s): Professor of sociology at the Frankfurt School, West Germany.
Habermas examines Bataille's views on modernity, postmodernity, and social theory.
The philosophical discourse on modernity and postmodernity.
Sixteenth and seventeenth century Spanish and French mysticism, part 1
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Sponsored by: Society for the Humanities.
deCerteau discusses literary mysticism in 16th and 17th century Spain and France.
Foucault's unmasking of the human sciences
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Speaker(s): Professor of sociology at the Frankfurt School, West Germany.
Habermas examines the role of society in creating sciences' "great men".
The philosophical discourse on modernity and postmodernity.
The final fifty days of the presidential campaign
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Speaker(s): Thomas is a journalist who covers the White House.

Thomas outlines the last days of the 1984 presidential campaign, discusses Reagan as President, and explains the relationship of the media with the President, in general, and with Reagan, in particular.
Homosexuality and initiation in ancient Greece
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Sponsored by: Andrew D. White Professors-At-Large Program.
Dover discusses representations of and interest in homosexuality in ancient Greece, particularly relating to adolescent initiation into adulthood.
Sixteenth and seventeenth century Spanish and French mysticism, part 2
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Sponsored by: Society for the Humanities.
deCerteau discusses the development of mysticism in Spain and France.
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Panel members discuss the interrelationship between language, literature and nationalism.
Sixteenth and seventeenth century Spanish and French mysticism, part 4
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Sponsored by: Society for the Humanities.
de Certeau analyzes Juan de la Cruz's poetry in light of Spanish mysticism.
Sixteenth and seventeenth century Spanish and French mysticism, part 3
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Sponsored by: Society for the Humanities.
In his third lecture of the series, Certeau discusses "higher literature", its mystical content, and interpretations of it in 17th and 18th century Europe.
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Ikiriye discusses the increasing influence of Western culture on Japanese society.
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Sponsored by: Center for World Community,Interreligious International Ministries Committee (IRIM).

Pempel discusses yin and yang, or feminine and masculine characteristics, and the need for more yin in our society. She asserts that we must begin to concentrate more on being than on doing and to make time for solitude.
Jazz and literary culture in Czechoslovakia today
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Sponsored by: Russian Literature, Department of.

Skovorecky discusses the Communist repression of the Czech government, especially in the literary and musical fields, since 1968. Particular attention is paid to the development of jazz and punk rock music in Czechoslovakia, the necessary ideological compromises with the present regime, the domestic sources of information on music composed in Czechoslovakia, and the realities of "culture control" by the authorities in this area.
The humanities in everyday life and public policy
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Sponsored by: Society for the Humanities.

The five speakers discusss topics such as the problems facing foreign-language students in American universities, conflicts over the distribution of the National Endowment for the Humanities funds, and the need for public acknowledgement of foreign cultural concerns by the National Endowment for the Humanities.
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.

Katzenstein speaks of Reagan's attempts to reestablish the patriarchal family as predominant in the U.S. Feldman speaks of Reagan's attempts to curtail federal medical assistance for the elderly, a disproportionate number of whom are living in poverty.
Sixteenth and seventeenth century Spanish and French mysticism, part 5
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Sponsored by: Society for the Humanities.
de Certeau discusses the criteria necessary for recognizing mystical texts as such and suggests ways in which mystical texts may be analyzed.
Ulysses' brother: the Cain and Abel theme in Dante and Machiavelli
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Quinones describes the history of the Cain and Abel theme in literature, emphasizing Dante's use of it in the character of Ulysses and Machiavelli's "revolutionary" application of it in his work.
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Sponsored by: Asian-American coalition,University Unions Programming Board,Africana Studies and Research Center.

McAdams points to the weaknesses in Reagan's economic policy while Greve defends it. Ranney emphasizes social justice concerns while Jachson focuses on the long-term societal effects of Reagan's policies.
Taking control of evolution: genetic manipulation and its consequences for various species
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Sponsored by: Andrew D. White Professors-At-Large Program.
Woolhouse describes the way in which scientists produce new hybrids by genetic manipulation.
Can social change be achieved through the United States' political system?
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Goodstein discusses social change which has occurred during the past 20 years and its implications for the U.S. political system.
Berlin architecture and urban design since 1900
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Kleihues describes several of the civic designs which were suggested for Berlin during the period 1900-1965.
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Sponsored by: Center for World Community,Interreligious International Ministries Committee (IRIM).

Weisskopf discusses nuclear war, the cold war, and the present realities of the Strategic Defense Initiative (SDI). He describes the work of antinuclear activists and their influence on public policy.
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Kleihues describes the current architectual designs being used in the renovation of inner-city Berlin.
James McCourt reads from "Time Out of Mind"
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Sponsored by: Council on the Creative and Performing Arts.
McCourt reads from his work in progress, "Time Out of Mind".
Talk on what makes "60 Minutes" tick
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Sponsored by: Sigma Delta Chi,Cornell Daily Sun,The Society of Professional Journalists.
Socolow chronicles the history of "60 Minutes".
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Speaker(s): Katzenstein is a professor in the Government Department, Cornell.
Katzenstein emphasizes the contradictory elements inherent in the German reunification question.
East Germany, West Germany and the Soviet Union: the changing relationship.
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Sponsored by: Andrew D. White Professors-At-Large Program.
Borlaug discusses various social and political influences on the development of agriculture and international agricultural policy.
Masking and unmasking of photography in post-modernism
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Speaker(s): Grundberg is a visiting artist.
Grundberg defines postmodernism and describes its importance.
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Sponsored by: Women's Studies Program,University Health Services.
Caplan describes a number of ideas which surround sex differences, particularly those which relate to female "masochism".
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Sponsored by: Society for the Humanities.
Speaker(s): LaCapra is director of the Society for the Humanities and is a professor in the History department, Cornell.
LaCapra describes the relationship of the novel to history and briefly chronicles intellectual history, interpreting and defining the novel through its relation to history.
One culture: creative modes common to the arts and sciences
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Sponsored by: Society for the Humanities.
Hoffmann discusses the rift between scientists and humanists. He presents three case studies of chemistry, poetry, and visual arts and describes the similarities common to these fields.
Has the Labour Party a future in British politics?
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Speaker(s): Sheerman is a British politician.
Sheerman discusses the British parliament, its history as it relates to the Labour party, and its possibilities for the future.
Women, development and the international economy
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Sponsored by: City and Regional Planning, Department of,Women's Studies Program.
Speaker(s): Beneria is a member of the economics department at Rutgers University. (In 1986, she joined the faculty in the department of City and Regional Planning, Cornell.)
Beneria discusses the involvement of women in economic development around the world and describes the manner in which research has evolved in this field over the past 15 years.
Popular support and the stability of the liberal democratic party regime in Japan
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.

Kabashima discusses the processes which helped maintain the power of the Liberal Democratic Party (LDP) for the last 30 years, particularly in reference to political corruption and the political system's reaction to it.
Agricultural policy in the United States: political and economic dimensions
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Sponsored by: Biology and Society Major.
Robinson discusses American agricultural policy and its successful economic impact. Lowi discusses American politics' effect on agriculture through history, focusing on economic changes.
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Sponsored by: German Literature, Department of,Women's Studies Program.
Culler discusses Habermas' notion of communication and literary principles and his study of language in its relation to action. Mohanty serves as discussant.
The utopian dimension in communicative ethics
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Sponsored by: German Literature, Department of,Women's Studies Program.
Benhabib explains the latent utopianism evident in Habermas' view of communicative ethics. Miller serves as discussant.
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Williams and Burak discuss the topic of student activism and political orientation of Cornell students at the present as compared to the 1960's.
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Powers chronicles the events which led to World War I and presents them as a warning against current military policies.
Eudora Welty reads her short story "The Wide Net"
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Sponsored by: Andrew D. White Professors-At-Large Program.
Welty reads her short story, "The Wide Net".
Tobias Wolff reads his own work.
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Sponsored by: Creative Writing Program,National Endowment for the Arts.
Wolff reads from his works "Sister" and "The Rich Brother".
Survey research and presidential campaigns: the Democrats in 1984
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Sponsored by: Cornell Institute for Social and Economic Research (CISER).
Lynch describes the use of polls in presidential campaigns, specifically the 1984 campaign.
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Sponsored by: University Unions Programming Board.
Wilson discusses the capabilities and effects of the supercomputer presently being installed at Cornell.
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Sponsored by: Women's Studies Program,Society for the Humanities,Latin American Studies Program,Near Eastern Studies, Department of.
ElSaadawi discusses the oppression of women in the Third World by imperialist powers and by men in the household and suggests ways in which this oppression hinders creativity.
Civil rights: where do we go from here?
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Speaker(s): Chairman of the U.S. Civil Rights Commission.
Pendleton describes the problem of discrimination in the United States and suggests some solutions to it.
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Sponsored by: Andrew D. White Professors-At-Large Program.
Derrida translates, reads, and discusses the work of Heidegger.
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Sponsored by: Student Finance Commission,Committee on United States-Latin American Relations (CUSLAR).
Panel discusses several aspects of the CIA: recruitment on campus, international law and involvement in Central America, an "inside" view of the organization, and current CIA operations in Nicaragua.
Breaking with Moscow: revelations of a Soviet diplomat
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Sponsored by: Center for International Studies.
Speaker(s): Soviet defector and former Soviet diplomat.
Shevchenko describes his own experiences as a Soviet diplomat and as a defector from the Soviet Union and discusses US-USSR relations.
West German parties and their politics
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Speaker(s): Member of the Free Democratic Party.
Adan-Schaetzer discusses West German political parties and social political conditions in West Germany.
Outward glance and inward retreat: ambivalence in African arts and literature
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Sponsored by: Society for the Humanities.
Soyinka provides a detailed analysis of African art and discusses Western attitudes toward it.
Culture and imperialism: overlapping territories, intertwined histories
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Said examines the intertwined relationship between history, culture, and imperialism.
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Said describes the "imperialist vision" as it is manifested in culture, especialy in literature.
Culture and imperialism: opposition and resistance
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Said describes the political and cultural subjugation of non-Western culture and explains changes in the nature of imperialism.
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Said explains the history, current perspective, and impact of colonialism and imperialism.
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Vlastos discusses and defines common uses of irony by referring to the classical works of Aristotle and Socrates.
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Sponsored by: Society for the Humanities.
Randel explains how musicologists define "Western art music" and mentions some of the problems scholars have with music definition.
The metamorphosis of perception through production
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Sponsored by: History and Philosophy of Science and Technology, Program in the.

McCleary discusses technology, emphasizing architecture, and its interaction with society. He proposes that experience and knowledge of the world is through "levels of mediation with the physical world".
Latin America and the West: historical origins and cultural contexts--#4: The West we knew
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Sponsored by: Society for the Humanities.
Speaker(s): Fuentes is a noted Mexican author and critic.
Fuentes looks at the Spanish legacy of Latin America and the situation at the end of the 15th century and beginning of the 16th century.
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.

Vlastos claims that there are two different Socrates, one which might be called "historical" and the other which might be called "philosophical". He asserts that the "second" Socrates is prevalent in Plato's writings.
The feminist movement today: a historical perspective
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Sponsored by: Women's Studies Program,Telluride Association.
Ehrenreich talks about the gains women have made through the feminist movement but focuses mainly on the problems that women still face, particularly abortion, sexuality, and economic rights.
Latin America and the West: historical origins and cultural contexts--#8: The revolutions of independence
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Sponsored by: Society for the Humanities.
Speaker(s): Fuentes is a noted Mexican author and critic.

Fuentes describes the turmoil and reforms of 18th century Spain and how they contributed to a loss of power over Spanish lands in the New World, resulting in the wars leading to the independence of Latin America from Spain.
Socratic rejection of the Lex talionis
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Vlastos describes the conflict between the views of Socrates and the Lex Talionis, the ancient doctrine of retaliation.
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Speaker(s): Rodriquez was a trade unionist forced to flee El Salvador.
Using a translator, Rodriquez describes his own experiences of the current chaotic situation in El Salvador.
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Kishwar describes the goals and works of "Manushi," an Indian journal about women and society, and answers questions concerning civil rights problems in India.
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Sponsored by: Palestine Human Rights Committee (PHRC).
Speaker(s): Habiby is a founding member of the Palestinian Communist Party and editor- in-chief of the largest Arabic paper in Israel.
Habiby traces the history of a systematic policy of the State of Israel from 1948 to the present of eliminating Arabs from Israel.
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Speaker(s): Lecturer founded the Jewish Defense League and is a member of Israel's parliament, the Knesset.
Kahane presents his views on the state of Israel and the presence of Arabs in Israel while responding to a hostile, heckling crowd.
U.S. international and security policy: the right turn' in historical perspective
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Speaker(s): Lecturer is Professor of Linguistics at Massachusetts Institute of Technology, prominent speaker and author in linguistics and social issues.

Chomsky analyzes the activity of the Reagan administration as a right turn' in U.S. government policy, citing such things as a transfer of resources from the poor to the wealthy, an increase in state power and economic control, and an activist foreign policy.
Human rights violations in the Soviet Union and El Salvador
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Speaker(s): Orlov is a physicist at Cornell who was recently allowed to emigrate from the Soviet Union. Dudley is coordinator of CUSLAR.
The speakers discussed human rights violations in the Soviet Union and El Salvador and answered questions from the audience. Orlov used an interpreter.
Nature unveiling before science: images of women and knowledge
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Sponsored by: Society for the Humanities,Women's Studies Program.
Jordanova formulates a correlation between the unveiling of women's bodies and actions in art, science and medicine.
Women, science, and the body: discourses and representations.
What is there about the White House that makes its occupants want to do bad things?
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Sponsored by: Summer Session, Extramural Study, and Related Programs, Division of.
Speaker(s): Professor of Government, Cornell University.
Lowi argues that deception and bad policy making in the Executive Branch arise from the cold war culture and the plebiscitory presidency.
The autonomy of the arts and the administration of culture
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Salo discusses the state supported art system in Finland.
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Speaker(s): Playwright; Former Minister of Culture in Finland; Former head of the Finnish Social Democratic Party.
Salo gives an overview of Finland's "westernization".
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Sponsored by: German Literature, Department of,Society for the Humanities.

Otto addresses the relationship between fascism and architecture, focusing on the single case study of the 1927 Stuttgart architectural exhibition. He suggests that architecture held an obsessive importance for the Nazis.

The three speakers discussed the need for modifications within the various libraries on campus.

Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.

Saltpeter describes his involvement in scietific consultation regarding government military projects.
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.

Swaminathan explains the benefits and concerns of the green revolution.
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.

Otto traces the history of Neumann's various architectural endeavors.
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Sponsored by: Jewish Awareness Network,Cornell Political Forum.
Speaker(s): Member of the Israeli Knesset.

Kahane tells stories of Jews being killed in Israel, stories which he claims are never heard in the popular press. He speaks of a contradiction between zionism and Western democracy noting that the development of a Jewish state necessitates a locale with a majority of Jews. This, he says, is contrary to democracy which relies on numerical superiority to define the "majority".

Two native American Indian poets read from their works.

Salinger discusses his experiences as a news correspondent and his views regarding American foreign policy, including his encouragement for individuals to be involved and informed regarding current affairs.

Turner discusses her slides which show different aspects of interior design.
New York State capital in Albany: preservation, planning, architectural history, and photography.

Hart discusses the importance of politics in everyone's lives and calls for a theme of excellence in the country's education, domestic spending, foreign policy and outlook for the future.

Von Weizsacker explains his personal view of philosophy and the philosophy of science.
Philosophical and political consequences of modern science.

Weizsacker holds that scientists should feel responsible for the social, political and ecological consequences of modern science and technology and should act accordingly.
Philosophical and political consequences of modern science.

Chavez presents the movement of the United Farm Workers to boycott California grapes due to the alleged use of pesticides and unfair labor practices by growers.

Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.

Tienhoven presents the concept of teaching through personal insights and techniques. He argues that teaching is a two-way street which requires critical thinkingfrom both teacher and student.
Teaching in a changing world: dilemmas and challenges.
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Speaker(s): Mr. LaFeber is Professor of American History at Cornell. Mr. Katzenstein is Professor of Government at Cornell.

LaFeber and Katzenstein both address the question of America on the decline, with LaFeber providing a historical account of how the decline has happened and Katzenstein suggesting some solutions to it.
Luigi Einaudi: between politics and history
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.

Einaudi Inaugural Lecture; Chartier, the first recipient of the Einaudi professorship in European and International Studies, discusses the life of Luigi Einaudi and his contributions to Italian intellectual history.
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Sponsored by: Mortar Board Honor Society,Cornell Political Forum,Cornell Republicans,Cornell Democrats.

Speaker(s): Keene is chairman of the American Conservative Union; Yepsen is a reporter for the Des Moines Register; Frankovic is director of surveys for the CBS News Election Unit and a 1968 Cornell graduate; Ginsberg is a government professor at Cornell; Chapman, who serves as moderator, is the executive director of the Cornell News Service and a former bureau chief for ABC News.
Discussants address the question "is this democracy?" in relation to the 1988 presidential election.

Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Sponsored by: East Asia Program,Dean's Office of the Graduate School,Johnson Graduate School of Management Federation of Alumni from Taiwan.
Speaker(s): Representative of the Coordination Council for North American Affairs, a non-diplomatic mission maintained by the Nationalist Chinese government in the United States.
Discusses the relationship between the Republic of China and the United States on both an economic and political level, particularly after the U.S. non-recognition of Taiwan in 1979.
On the rhetoric of racism in literature
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Sponsored by: Society for the Humanities.
Tape includes introductory remarks by La Capra; Gates presents an overview of the state of black education in the United States today and opens the conference "Race and the Humanities".
Contesting the dominant other: the case of the Francophone North African writer
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Speaker(s): Assistant Professor of Near Eastern Studies, Cornell University.

Mehrez discusses the recent development of bilingual writing among Francophone writers (specifically Arab) as being distinct from the currently-existing alternatives of writing in French while adhering to a metropole perspective or of immersing oneself in Arabic. She points out the political implications of such a choice.
Future of peace in the middle east: an arab perspective
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Speaker(s): Ambassador Maksoud is the permanent observer of the League of Arab States to the United Nations, and chief representative of the Arab League to the United States.

Maksoud advances the notion that due to the establishment of the state of Israel, the Palestinians have ceased to be human beings and have become human obstacles. What is needed, in his mind, is a Palestinian adaptation to the Israeli "fear psyche".
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Speaker(s): Author of "The Lost Pilot," "Absences," and "Constant Defender"; Professor of English, Amherst College.
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Speaker(s): Associate professor at Wellsley College.

MacIntosh discusses pedagogy as a means of allowing students to adaopt an "adjacent" position in relation to subject matter. This approach is an alternative to the "lateral", "take a position" point of view.
The Gorbachev reforms: a relationship between human rights and mutual security
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Speaker(s): Orlov is a Soviet physicist who was imprisonned in the Soviet Union because of his human rights activism. He is now a researcher at Cornell in the Physics Department.
Orlov discusses the current situation in the Soviet Union in view of "glasnost" and suggests that the withdrawal of Soviet troops from Afghanistan is unique in the history of the Soviet Union.
Gorbachev and Soviet reform: insights on the present and future.
The black church and oppositional politics
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Sponsored by: Society for the Humanities.
Speaker(s): West is from the Union Theological Seminary.

West discusses the "Black Church" and its oppositional politics (ie., the use of prophetic, all-embracing vision) and its consequences in terms of both enabling and disabling causes of freedom. She is introduced by Hortense Spillers, visiting professor of English, Cornell University.
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Sponsored by: Society for the Humanities,See CU 2793 for additional sponsors.

Piedra compares Latin American song with North American blues.

Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.

Barrett describes a new feminist interest in the body which varies significantly from the work of Foucault and from recent discussions of cyborgs. She suggests that this new interest is tied to the broader feminist concern with the politics of reproductive choice.

Evans presents a study of the architecture of centralized Renaissance churches with emphasis on the manner in which meaning is conveyed.

Speaker(s): British scholar, currently a visiting professor at Harvard.

Evans explains what he sees as the three phases of fragmentation in 20th century architecture: cubism and its application to architecture, function and the humanizing of architectural firm, and the decentering of the subject.

Schorr criticizes the role of television in politics today, focusing on Ronald Reagan's successful manipulation of television to weave his fantasies into a reality for the American public.

Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Sponsored by: University Events (Public Affairs), Office of.
Speaker(s): Senior news analyst for National Public Radio.
Schorr outlines Reagan's three major attributes: speech reading, small talk, and ineptitude in dealing with spontaneous affairs. He addresses the president's popularity and his future legacy.

Meese gives an overview of Reagan's administration and addresses the challenges facing President-elect Bush in his upcoming administration.

Naylor describes the development of her literary voice and suggests that the legion of voices which have preceded her have molded hers into what it is today.

Taylor discusses the mechanisms involved in measuring time with an atomic clock, and covers related aspects of pulsars and relativity.

Colby and Beitz discuss the politics of covert action, debating on such aspects as secrecy and efficacy.
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.

Sedgwick describes the nature of homosexuality as portrayed in Melville's "Billy Budd". She examines the subject through analysis of characters and conflicts and discusses the effect of AIDS on current homosexual definition.

Shammas discusses the intransience of the Palestinian Intifadeh uprisings and the extent to which its negative implications for Israel are transformed to more acceptable conclusions by and for Israelis.

Thandekile Mvusi of Mount Holyoke College was originally scheduled to make this presentation, but was unable to attend the conference. Washington steps in to provide her own rough interpretation of this subject, discussing the acculturation process in America today in which Blacks lose their identitities and conform to white society.
Women of color in the United States.
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Sponsored by: Cornell University Program Board,Sigma Phi Fraternity.
Speaker(s): Weddington defended Jane Roe in the landmark Roe vs. Wade Supreme Court case. Schlafly headed the campaign that defeated the ratification of the ERA.

Weddington and Shlafly debate the ethical aspects of abortion and the future of legislation on abortion in the United States. Weddington argues that abortion is a woman's legal and moral right of choice; Shlafly argues that abortion is murder and should be made illegal.
Molly Hite and Fred Muratori read from their works
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.

Fulfilling our destiny: self-empowerment in the face of oppression
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Speaker(s): Kwame Toure, formerly known as Stokely Carmichael, is the former prime minister of the Black Panthers.

Toure discusses the ties of black people to Africa, the ways in which they are discriminated against in America through capitalism and oppression, and the need for blacks to unite in a conscious effort to stop injustice.
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Sponsored by: Public Interest Law Union,Cornell Civil Liberties Union,Law School.
Speaker(s): American Civil Liberties Union Executive Director.

Explains the historical and political context of civil liberties in the United States. Shows how the Constitution expresses civil rights and how rights are gained. Discusses the political climate surrounding civil rights today, detailing the threats posed by groups like the Moral Majority.
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Sponsored by: Cornell University Program Board,Alpha Delta Phi Fraternity.

Mailer talks of his involvement with the group of writers who spoke out against the Ayatollah Khomeni's death threats to Salmon Rushdie and against Walden Books, who pulled Rushdie's book, "Satanic Verses", from their shelves. He recounts the meeting between the writers and a group of Black Muslims to come to some understanding of their opposing positions. He tries to convey a sense of what Khomeni's threat symbolized to Western writers.

Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.

Lecture, April 13, 1992, 4:30 pm, Lecture Room D, Goldwin Smith Hall.
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Sponsored by: Society for the Humanities.
Speaker(s): Professor of the History of Philosophy, Ecole des Hautes Etudes en Science Sociales, Paris; former A.D. White Professor-at-Large.

Derrida attempts to more closely define death and some of the semantics that surround it. Quoting extensively from Heiddeger, he discusses the limitations on knowledge of death and death's transferable, ever-pervasive property. NOTE: Speaker pauses in the first few moments of the lecture while a P.A. problem is corrected. 2-3 minutes of associated hum on the tape is quickly corrected.
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Sponsored by: Society for the Humanities.
Speaker(s): Professor of the History of Philosophy, Ecole des Hautes Etudes en Sciences Sociales, Paris; Former A.D. White Professor-At-Large.

Derrida examines the concept of death and of "Dasein" as analyzed by Heidegger in his his text "Being and Time". In exploring the various constructions of death, he incorporates linguistical analyses as well as a comparison to other domains such as anthropology and history. He also argues that, although Heidegger denies the link, his analysis is not possible without a Judeo-Christian concept of death
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Sponsored by: Art, Department of,Johnson Museum of Art.
Speaker(s): Visual artist, a retrospective of whose work is on exhibit at the Johnson Museum of Art, Fall 1992.

In this lecture, delivered during a retrospective of her work at the Johnson Art Museum at Cornell, Fall 1992, Denes reflects on themes of her work as a visual artist such as mapping the invisible, mapping thoughts, the discovery of truth, reality and misconception. Specific works described include her "Pyramid Series", in which she translates Pascal's triangle into visual form, "Tree Mountain", and "Wheat Field".
Nancy G. Dickenson visiting artist lectures.
Light, space and form: the heart of architecture
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Sponsored by: Architecture, College of,Trustee Council, Cornell University.

Meier discusses the role of light in arhictecture, citing his own architecture in particular. He discusses the different aspects of architecture for different kinds of buidlings, focusing especially on museums. He analyzes the relationship between landscape and architecture, and concludes that space, light, and form are the heart of architecture.
How to get a job like mine
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Sponsored by: Spencer T. and Ann W. Olin Foundation.

Speaking to a capacity audience of over 2,000 people at Bailey Hall, a congenial and unrestrained Vonnegut expresses opinions on such varied topics as the importance of community, social justice, literature, the weather, educational reform, war, censorship, technology, TM, Charles Manson, and Perry Mason. He also reccounts his experiences as a Cornell undergraduate in the 1940s.
Spencer T. and Ann W. Olin lectures.
What is good design, and do we see any on the Cornell campus?
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Sponsored by: College of Achitecture, Art and Planning.

In his seminar, part of the 1993 Alumni Weekend, Hascup discusses various locations or structures on the Cornell campus which exhibit "good design" principles. Some of these locations include the Arts Quad, the Johnson Art Museum, the McGraw clock tower at Uris Library, the Law School buidlings, and the Performing Arts Center.
Modern architecture and the mass media
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Sponsored by: Architecture, Art and Planning, College of,Architecture Department.
Speaker(s): Professor of architecture, Princeton University.
Colomina examines the interplay between high and mass culture, and the influence of that interaction, along with the advertising techniques of the technological revolution, on modern architecture.
Publicity and privacy: modern architecture as mass media.
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Sponsored by: Near Eastern Studies, Department of,History of Art, Department of.
Speaker(s): University Professor of Islamic Studies, George Washington University; Andrew D. White Professor-at-Large, Cornell.

In this second in a series of three lectures, Nasr first discusses the presence of calligraphy in Islamic art, as well as the extensive use of complex geometry in design. He then introduces the topic of hierarchy in Islamic art, noting that, as in the West, architecture is preeminent, while art that is closest to the individual, such as clothing, is secondary. He notes that Islamic architecture's primary function is to promote quiet or peace.
The philosophy and meaning of art in Islam.
Bei Dao and contemporary chinese poetry
Recorded in Ithaca, NY by Cornell University.
Accompanied by: Conference program;List of poems read by Bei Dao (list in English);Handouts to accompany Lazer's talk: Five poems by Che Qianzi (in Chinese and with English translations).

Sponsored by: University Lectures Committee,Society for the Humanities,Cornell Council for the Arts,Office of the Dean, College of Arts and Sciences,Comparative Literature, Department of,English, Department of,German Studies, Department of,Romance Studies, Department,Theatre Arts, Department of,Africana Studies and Research Center,Asian-American Studies Program,Creative Writing Program, Department of English,East Asia Program,Hispanic-American Studies Program,Women's Studies Program.
Speaker(s): Dao is a Chinese poet. Huang is from SUNY-Buffalo. Zhen, Gunther and Lazer are from the University of Alabama.

Bei Dao reads from his work. -- The reception of Chinese poetry in the U.S. -- Against the allegorical typology: new trends in contemporary Chinese poetry. -- Metamorphosing poetics: writing the body, writing the text. -- Character, self, and sumbol: the poetry of Che Qianzi and Bei Dao.
Reading and Panel, March 31, 1995, 8:00pm, HEC Aud., Goldwin Smith.

After four local scholars read one poem each by Bei Dau in English, the author reads his work in the original Chinese. Huang discusses the acceptance and interpretation of this and other Chinese poetry in the United States. Gunther comments on the body as a metaphor both within and without poetry. Zheng speaks on the course of general trends in contemporary Chinese poetry. Lazer elaborates on the visual structure of Chinese poetry in its original characters versus English translations (see handouts).
Past, present, future tense: a conference on contemporary poetry.
